pars: The Rushworth Hotel (Bottom Pub) held its annual Charity Auction and Raf e for the Royal Children’s Hospital on Good Friday evening, and proprietors Maz and Andy are thrilled with the 2017 result - an extraordinary $9205.45 raised to help maintain the vital work of this unique medical establishment.

By 7.30, the Pub was packed with patrons ready to buy up big in support of the Hospital; some bidding for goods that they may not need, others securing items that they immediately donated back to the Hotel to augment its decor!
Sporting memorabilia was popular, as were the vast array of tools and household appliances assembled for the sale.
There was even a pale blue vehicle bonnet, lovingly restored and emblazoned with an image of the pub and a reminder of its outstanding support of the Royal Children Hospital Appeal.

rushworth-the-place-to-be.title: Rushworth at Easter - the place to be
pars: Rushworth has become a go-to place for the Easter weekend with crowds turning up from all over the region and beyond to experience all the fun of the Festival on Saturday and the Moora Muster of working draught horses on Sunday.

The Lions Club’s traditional Wood and Produce Auction is still a highlight of the day. Hilder’s Block at 10 am is the time and place for your chance to bid for quality  rewood and local produce. And of course you have the added satisfaction of knowing your purchases contribute to the worthy causes supported by Rushworth & District Lions Club.
The market will be ready for business from 8 am with over one hundred stalls  lling the streetscape on High Street.

In addition to fare from our local food outlets, there will be Indian, Dutch, Asian and good old Aussie bbq cuisine to choose from in the food department. You will not go hungry and your taste-buds may be even delighted.

Children will be treated to a free Easter Egg hunt at the Community House at 11.30 am. Pete the Clown on his penny farthing will also be giving away eggs between 12 pm and 2 pm. Popcorn, fairy  oss, toffee apples, and slushies will also undoubtedly delight the children - if not the parents! - and free showbags will be an added attraction. (Free kids’ activities at the Shire Hall might just help use up some of that sugar-fuelled energy!)
After checking out the exhibitions and displays you may need a spell from all the excitement and you can rest your weary feet at the rotunda while listening to music by Southern Cross.
The Parade

At 1 pm the much anticipated ‘Grand Parade’ will take place - there are always some surprises on the day, so who knows how many old and new vehicles and other ambulatory bodies will take to the street.
Photo competition

If you are good with your camera, some good snaps on the day may win you $500! Go online and register your photo (check terms and conditions) at www.rushworthfestival.org. The photos submitted will be used to make a calendar for next year.

And, last but not least, don’t forget to look out for our raf e tickets at the REHF stall. At $1 ticket, you can win tokens to the value of $1000 ( rst prize), $500 (second prize), $250 (third prize) to spend in town at most of the local retailers - a bonus for the winner and for the town!
Sunday at Moora

On Sunday the Moora Recreation Reserve will be where it’s all happening. As well as the popular working horses, there will be heaps of other ‘country life’ entertainment, with demonstrations of old-style farm skills and displays of bush crafts and folk art.
A great way to  nish off an action packed Rushworth weekend!

rushworth-court-house.title: New book on Rushworth’s historic Court House
pars: Rushworth Court House is re-awakening. Waranga News of 30 March reported on plans to remove bats and white ants, and to appoint local management. Now the imposing old building, built in 1877, is featured in a new book by local historian and News writer Alan McLean, titled “Order in the Court!”

The book shows the Court House has witnessed an extraordinary passing parade, some arriving on foot, others tying a horse to a nearby rail or tree. The building welcomed “an able-bodied specimen of the loa ng fraternity”. Another defendant challenged the nasal senses, being “as shy of water as he was of work”. More than one went up for endangering lives by “furious riding”.

In 1887, after 18 years as a Justice of the Peace, Wolton Wigg, a local brewer, was called into the dock, not to his preferred seat on the Bench. Found in a boat with a gun and a bag of dead game birds, he strangely pleaded “not guilty”! The good J.P. was convicted and  ned for shooting ducks out of season. His career on the Bench continued but his days hearing poaching charges were over.

In 1898, a well-known Rushworth woman was accused of “pilfering and behaving in a way not conducive to the morality of the township”. She went to Bendigo gaol, found guilty of being a “disorderly prostitute”. If only she had been a little more orderly...

Some left the Court House escorted across a paddock to “compulsory retirement in the logs” for a short period. Others won a longer visit to “Her Majesty’s boarding house”, referring to Queen Victoria.

A predecessor timber Court House was hastily built in 1857. Not attending to face charges was a once well-respected local bank manager, Lowson Salmon. He and the bank’s cash left the district coincidentally one night in 1860, never to be seen again.

Even before that original building was constructed and within six months of the discovery of gold in 1853, two visitors to the local diggings went straight to Melbourne’s Supreme Court where they were convicted of separate crimes at Moora and Rushworth. Both were hanged in Melbourne Gaol.

In 1857, three men went down for “highway robbery” near Rushworth’s Criterion Hotel. The Moora hotels, the Wanalta hotel and several hotels at Whroo also had their share of unwanted action. In a major shock, the book  nds that some pubs traded outside legal hours!

More than one publican was  ned for operating an unlicensed billiard table. Others were found guilty of allowing unauthorised dancing in their “public houses”. Law and order in the district were plainly under serious attack from the forces of evil!

Brawling Chinamen,  ghting farmers, horse thieves, aggressive foul-mouthed drunks, passive drunks, cadgers, owners of sly-grog shanties, swagmen carrying more than their own goods (usually in a bottle), owners of destructive wandering goats and pigs, carriers who neglected to put their name on their cart, a man found at night in Wigg’s brewery, and a mother of 14 who failed to send her eldest child to school for the speci ed number of days. All passed through the Court House door, each earning a place in the book.
Lucky to avoid a visit in 1883 were Murchison loafers and vagrants who had “thoroughly mastered the art of living on nix, and getting drunk on the pro ts!”
These colourful characters, and many more, bring to life the  rst  fty years of settlement at Rushworth, Colbinabbin, Corop, Gobarup, Moora, Stanhope, Toolleen, Wanalta, Whroo, and Murchison.
Alan’s book will be available for purchase during the Easter festivities at Rushworth, from Stanhope Newsagency, and from Rushworth Gift and Variety, at just $23.

rushworth-p-12-memorial-thanks.title: P-12 College thanked for memorial help
pars: Local schools played a signi cant role in the recent activities to commemorate the extraordinary bravery and skill exhibited by two of Rushworth’s most illustrious sons, Air Vice-Marshal Frank McNamara VC CBE CB and Air Marshal Sir George Jones KBE CB DFC. Hundreds of people attended the unveiling of statues to the two men adjacent to the War Memorial in High Street, and the event received nationwide attention in the media.

Co-hosted by Rushworth RSL Sub-Branch and the RAAF, the event commemorated the awarding of a Victoria Cross Medal to locally born aviator, Frank McNamara, after whom McNamara House at Rushworth P-12 College is named.
Current Year 12 students of the College - alma mater to both heroes - played an especially important role, presenting wreaths to dignitaries during the wreath-laying ceremony at the War Memorial.
By way of thanks, the RAAF presented each Year 12 student with a History of the Royal Australia Air Force between its formal foundation in 1921 and 2016, when the book was published.

Rushworth RSL representative Ian Riley - accompanied by wife Marion - recently attended a weekly College assembly to present the Year 12 students with their books on behalf of the RAAF. Especially notable recipients were 2016 College Dux Blake Rosenberg and McNamara House Co-Captain Kody Diegan, who spoke so eloquently on behalf of the College during the statue unveiling ceremony.
Everyone agreed that all of the Rushworth P-12 College students had “done their school and community proud”, and merited the praise lavished upon them from so many quarters.

travellers-experience-magic-of-india.title: Travellers experience India’s magic
pars: Excitement was high when, in early February, a group of 12 yoga students and friends met at Tullamarine Airport ready for adventure. They were heading off on the inaugural Sacred Earth Yoga Tour to India, a tour organised by Sue Barlow of the Mud Hut Yoga Studio, Rushworth. The idea was to create an opportunity to experience the wonders of India (the birth place of yoga) and at the same time to experience yoga in quite a different way from attending a regular class at a studio.

Needless to say, the excitement was well-justi ed, as was that little tinge of edgy anticipation - wondering just what was ahead for the travellers. From the moment of exiting the airport, India was everything one might have expected - and then add some! Immediately all of the senses are engaged in experiencing the land and its culture. The visual explosion of colourful saris, ceremonial  owers and sparkly ‘jewel’ encrusted wares, the cacophony of endless beeping horns in chaotic traf c of cars and rickshaws, the smells of incense and spice (and some of not so pleasant origin), the teeming pedestrian population of people old and young, of street vendors, of animals - sometimes camels and donkeys, but always, always COWS.
Here is one traveller’s account of some of the trip’s highlights. It’s just a little taste - as to do more than scratch the surface might require the pages of a small book!

The tour started in Delhi where we explored the bustling bazaars of Old Delhi by foot and by rickshaw. We visited an amazing Sikh temple where thousands of people are fed every day by volunteers and we became a little familiar with the sounds, smells and sights of India that would become our ‘norm’ for the next two weeks.

Our next stop was Agra where we saw the amazing, breathtaking Taj Mahal. Busy is an understatement! Indians visit the Taj four times in their lifetimes if possible: when they are born, when they are in school, when they are married and then when they take their own children. It was a Sunday when we visited – and they were all there – the whole 1.25 billion – well, not really, but it felt like that for those of us used to space and a lot less people!

From Agra, we visited Jaipur (the pink city), Pushkar (a holy city nestled on a lake on the edge of a desert) and Jodphur (the blue city). While we were in Jodphur we were lucky enough to attend three concerts that were part of the Sacred Spirit Festival. What an amazing experience. The evening concerts were held in the Mehrangarh Fort. The Fort was lit up against the night sky and the music was so very beautiful it is impossible to do justice by way of explanation. After this we travelled to Varanasi. This city is considered very holy and many pilgrims come to Varanasi to bathe in the Ganges River. It is considered auspicious to die and be cremated in Varanasi. This extremely busy and fascinating city is undergoing many changes at present, which will hopefully make life easier for the residents. This is only a brief snapshot of all the things we saw and experienced.

Throughout our tour, we had regular yoga classes which were designed to either prepare us for the day ahead or relax us and calm us for a good night’s sleep. We also attended a Laughter Yoga class in a park in Jaipur which was a lot of fun. Ridiculous really – but a lot of fun!! We also attended a community sunrise yoga class down by the Ganges while in Varanasi. The food and accommodation was excellent throughout. Our Indian guide, Amit, went out of his way to ensure we were informed, comfortable and enjoying ourselves. And, being a yogi himself, he even had us doing yoga on the bus some days. We walked, we talked, we ate, we laughed, we saw amazing sights and we all came home with a great appreciation for India.
In many ways, the highlight of the trip was the fantastic group of people. Everyone had a great time and we all enjoyed one another’s company.

heroes-remembered.title: Rushworth’s heroes remembered
pars: High St Rushworth was a colourful sight on Monday morning with rows of red crocheted poppies in the lawn, splendidly uniformed Defence Force dignitaries sporting lots of gold braid and many medals, and the Royal Australian Airforce Band adding to the atmosphere of excitement. The long-anticipated time had come for the unveiling of memorials in honour of two celebrated Rushworth heroes of World War 1, Air Vice-Marshal Frank McNamara and Air Marshal Sir George Jones.

Defence Force personnel, including the Chief of Defence Force, Air Chief Marshal Mark Binskin, AC, and the Chief of Air Force, Air Marshal Leo Davies, AO, CSC, joined with the Rushworth RSL, descendants of the celebrated airmen, community members, school children and visitors to commemorate the local Australian Flying Corps and Royal Australian Air Force heroes, exactly 100 years to the day since the sel ess act that awarded Air Vice-Marshal Frank McNamara the Victoria Cross.
The event, part of the Centenary of ANZAC 2014-2018 of cial commemoration, was the culmination of three years of planning and organisation by a special committee of Rushworth RSL.
In his address, Air Marshal Davies thanked the RSL. “It is important to reflect on our history and remember our forefathers,” he said.

colbo-lapathon-exceeds-target.title: Colbinabbin Lap-A-Thon exceeds target!
pars: Some of the 250 fresh-faced and full of energy Colbinabbin Lap-A-Thon walkers prepare to take off on their way to an enormously successful day to raise funds for the Melanoma Institute of Australia. Some $30,000 has been raised -with late donations still trickling in at the time of going to print.
More than 250 people took to the newly re-grassed Colbinabbin Recreation Reserve on 11 March 2017 to participate in the Colbinabbin Lap-A-Thon.
The Lap-A-Thon was held to raise money for the Melanoma Institute of Australia and will support  nding a cure for melanoma.
The inspiration behind the event was Colbo born and bred Lucinda Ryan, who is currently undergoing treatment for Stage 4 melanoma.

This year, a group of Lou’s friends – known as ‘The Moles’ decided to run a Lap-A-Thon in her now home town of Wongan Hills, WA. Lou’s Colbo family jumped on board with the idea of running a ‘sister’ event in Colbo on the same day. Prior to the day, participants collected sponsors through social media and online donations, or in person, with many seeking a donation per lap completed on the day.

vale-doris-barlow.title: Valé Doris Barlow
pars: 23 October 1925 – 25 February 2017

A much loved and highly respected resident of Rushworth, Doris Barlow was farewelled at St Paul’s Anglican Church and at a graveside ceremony at the Rushworth Lawn Cemetery, both of which were conducted by Fr. André Du Plooy, on the afternoon of Friday 3 March.
The esteem in which Doris was held was evident by the large number in attendance, with St Paul’s Church packed.

Among the family present were Doris’s sisters, Enid and Marion, and the family of her other sister, Jean, who was not well enough to attend. Also there were Doris’s daughter, Heather, and sons Ross, Colin and Neil, together with members of her extended family.
The tribute to Doris was presented by her son, Colin, on behalf of the family and forms the basis of the following information.
The early years

Doris was born in Natimuk on 23 October 1925 to James Palmer and his wife Ida (nee Pfennig). Three sisters followed: Jean, Enid and Marion. Her mother, known as Edie, died of pneumonia in Woodend at age 35, two months after Marion’s birth.
Doris attended Kyneton High School, and then went to Melbourne Teachers College, whilst living with her family who had transferred to Essendon.
The teacher
Doris first taught at an upper elementary school in the northern suburbs of Melbourne for a year, Yarram Upper Elementary for a year, then transferred to Rushworth.
Family life

It was at Rushworth that Doris met and married Robert Henry (Bob) Barlow, a third generation farmer. The wedding was in Essendon, and then Doris took on the duties of housewife, retiring from teaching after the initial eighteen months at Rushworth.
They lived on the family farm ‘Moorakyne’, speaking often of the candle and kerosene lighting days and irregular water supply, depending on the temperamental windmill on the Nine Mile Creek.

Bob and Doris had four children: Heather, Ross, Colin and Neil. She was thrilled by the arrival of Heather’s children (Narelle and David), Ross’s children (Alexandra and Andrew) and Colin’s children (Christopher, Matthew and Catherine), and loved knitting baby clothes as each new baby arrived. There are now six great grandchildren.
The friendship and support of neighbours were very much appreciated and Bob and Doris had a lot of fun playing tennis at Wanalta, and golf at Rushworth and further a field.
The move into Rushworth

The difculty of providing water and the absence of power on the farm led to Bob and Doris building a new solid brick house called ‘Wyeera’ in Moora Road, about the time Ross was born. This was the family home and continued to be Doris’s residence until frailty forced her into the Waranga Aged Care Hostel and then the Nursing Home.

Both Bob and Doris continued playing tennis and golf after shifting into Rushworth, until well into their sixties, and in the later years took up bowls as well. Many longstanding friendships that continued for the rest of their lives were initiated on the sporting  elds. Doris loved playing golf, not only at Rushworth, but also at Tatura and other surrounding clubs.
Love of travel
Doris travelled extensively in Australia, including the Canning Stock Route, Rabbit Flat, Ayers Rock and all the capital cities.
She also regularly ventured overseas to Europe, Asia, New Zealand and many other places.
Community involvement

Doris was involved in many community organisations over the years, including: The Council of Adult Education; Probus; The ‘buddy program’ at the school; Secretary of the Rushworth CAG (the Shire of Campaspe Advisory Group after the amalgamation of the shires); Neighbourhood Watch; Rushworth Senior Citizens; School and sporting club committees; The Waranga News.
Thank you

Colin concluded his address by saying, “On behalf of the family, I would like to sincerely thank the staff at the Waranga Aged Care Hostel and more recently the Nursing Home for the wonderful way they cared for Mum, and I must also thank Judy Ogden, Laurel Goggin, Nan Jessup and the many others who regularly visited and supported her whilst in care. Mum never failed to mention every time I visited her how lucky she was to be so well cared for at the Nursing Home.”
A life well lived
Doris’s life was certainly well lived. As Colin said in the eulogy, the family thought her life was best described in the words of the Frank Sinatra song, ‘I Did It My Way’.

draught-horses-working-for-easter.title: Working draught horses galore at moora for Easter
pars: Easter Sunday will see the staging of the 9th Moora Working Draught Horse Muster.

This wonderful ‘step back into the past’ event began in July 2009 with only seventeen ‘big horses’ and approximately 500 members of the public through the gate. We have grown over the years to such an extent that last Easter (2016) we had ninety-three ‘big horses’ all working throughout the day and 2000 to 3000 people through the gate. May I have a small boast by saying we are only W.A and the N.T. short of having horses coming from Australia wide to moora!

In 2010 we decided to move our event to Easter Sunday to complement the Rushworth Easter Heritage Festival held on Easter Saturday. By making it a two separate days weekend we hoped it would help bring extra people and tourists into the town and district and therefore be helping the local economic situation.
The 2013 Shire survey showed the two days bought close to half a million dollars into the town and district, something both committees are extremely proud of as we had all achieved our goal!
Community group/Event of the Year for 2014!
The icing on the cake was most de nitely our Rushworth Easter Heritage Festival being honoured with not only The Rushworth and District Award but the Shire of Campaspe’s Award too.

Now, with both committees in full  ight for this year’s Easter events and the days rushing by, time for a normal life-style has been shelved for several weeks. I know my friends and family don’t expect any sort of in-depth conversations with me that don’t involve heavy horses or what can be safe in the street parade!

Most of our Victorian “big boys” are all ready to roll. Some will be on the road for several hours to get here, but then, some from NSW, SA and our Queenslander can expect to be on the road not just hours but days! I just hope that our Tasmanian has a better trip over than last Easter, as he and his two beautiful big horses and the dog were twelve hours on the boat coming across in that dreadful storm the week before Easter. He wasn’t allowed down to the truck to check if the boys were safe and standing up or if they were down and cast. A terrifying trip over for them all.

When Raymond and I went out to the Moora Reserve early on the Friday morning to see if they had arrived and alright, we were met by four very exhausted travellers! Luckily horses and their slaves, plus dog, are very tough characters! After several feeds and sleeps they were all back on track again! Some of you may remember seeing them last year, the big coach with the two huge grey shire horses in the shafts both in the street parade on Saturday and working round at Moora on Sunday.

Our line-up this year will include all your old favourites that will be ploughing, harrowing, scarifying, and pulling sleds etc. There will also be a variety of different horse-drawn vehicles on parade for you to see and photograph. Plus, a line-up of different working displays. I’m excited because our own stationary baler has been set in order and working again. It was owned and used by the late Max Seamer who was the driving force behind our Working Draught Horse Muster and our founding member.

Salty’s hammering up a storm and old Dave will be giving him his usual cheek! Big Mick the rope-maker will be there with bells on, or so he tells me! Bill the packsaddle man is loaded up and hot to trot as is Wiltshire’s Harness store and the rest of our “Mug’s Alley” traders, not forgetting the camp oven scone man. Yum!

Michelle Bird, equine artist, after a lifetime spent with her beloved horses has turned to now drawing them. She captures their expressions beautifully! We are rapt to be able to have once again one of her framed works as  rst prize in our raf e. Last year’s picture was Rick’s big team and I am looking forward to seeing who will star in this year’s prize.

The craft demonstrators are gathering all their wares again. Lyn’s Ironbark Soy Melts and Rushlyn Studio’s hand-made cards, together with the folk-art ladies, are all brushed up and glued to their chairs, as are the Lace Making ladies with their  ne and fancy goods. Jenni’s Shed with her most beautiful leather goods just has me enraptured and Michelle will be displaying her beautiful pencil drawings; you can watch her creating a new work of art. All these wonderful people are more than happy to show and explain how they work.

The resident music makers are all getting warmed up to belt out all the old and new classics for you, so grab a cuppa and cake or lunch and sit, listen, and enjoy them! There are plenty of tables and chairs! The jumping castle man is back again too! Plus, heaps more!

Just give me a call if you want more information, or you can join in the fun by giving us a hand for an hour or so! Either way here’s my number/email 58561405 st-thoms2@ optusnet.com.au. Take care folks and see you all soon!
Hooroo from Maz

ride-for-youth-mental-health.title: Freemasons Cycling Club members ride for youth mental health
pars: Eight members of the Freemasons Cycling Club (Vic) and the five members of their support crew stopped at Rushworth on their four day ride from Wodonga to Ballarat to raise much-needed funds for the youth mental health service, headspace. Late on the morning of Thursday 2 March (on a very hot day) they took a break and enjoyed lunch at the Rushworth Bakery. That day they were riding from Shepparton to Bendigo, and in the local area they also took breaks at the Basin and at Colbinabbin.

The cyclists, Colin Prout, Malcolm Mann, Milton Mann, Matt DeNatris, Rod Pilmore, Darren Hill, Keith Stewart and Cyril Land, ranged in age from 48 to 69 years. Three of them came from Wodonga, with the others from Bacchus Marsh, Diggers Rest, Wangaratta, Tatura and Werribee.

Organiser of the ride, Malcolm Mann from Diggers Rest, told the Waranga News, ‘Members of the Freemasons Cycling Club (Vic) had previously ridden in events organised by others for charitable purposes, but we decided to ride to raise funds for a charity of our choice – the National Youth Mental Health Foundation, headspace.
‘All the riders in this event have been touched by mental illness within their families. If headspace had existed when our children were younger, it could have helped them substantially.’
headspace

The National Youth Mental Health Foundation, headspace, provides early intervention mental health services to 12 – 25 year olds, along with assistance in promoting young people’s wellbeing. The headspace programs cover four core areas: mental health, physical health, work and study support, and alcohol and other drug services.
Fundraising

100% of the funds raised during the ride went to headspace, with the riders and their support crew fully meeting all expenses incurred, including accommodation, meals, repairs to bicycles, and fuel for the support vehicles.
In addition to funds raised during the ride, the Freemason’s Foundation of Victoria provided a matching $1 for $1 donation up to $5,000.
At 11:35 am on the Thursday at Rushworth $3,570 had been raised for headspace on the everydayhero website.

At the end of the ride at Ballarat on Friday 3 March, following presentations by Milton Mann about the Freemasons Cycling Club (Vic) and Janelle Johnstone (Manager, Ballarat headspace) about the work of headspace in the local community, a cheque for $11,000 representing the total amount of funds raised by the Ride for headspace (as at 3 March) was presented to Ms Johnstone.

Ride organiser, Malcolm Mann told the Waranga News, ‘We’re appreciative of the support received along the way, including from the Rushworth Jubilee Lodge, those Lodges hosting awareness evenings for us, and all who made donations, including the Freemasons Foundation of Victoria.’ He added, ‘The event generally, and the total of funds raised in particular, exceeded all our expectations.’
You can still make a donation

If you would like to support the work of headspace you can still make a donation via the Freemasons Cycling Club (Vic) Ride on www.everydayhero.com/au, searching the word ‘Freemason’, and following the link to the ‘Give Now’ button. This website will remain open until 3 July 2017. Donations of $2 and more are tax deductible.

positive-partnerships-on-track.title: Reaction to track closure leads to positive partnerships
pars: Recent events in the Whroo State forest saw almost two hundred native trees and countless under-storey species destroyed in an effort to prevent trail-bike use.

This measure left some people with cause for concern about future access for visitors to the forest surrounding Rushworth but as Newton’s third law states; ‘For every action, there is an opposite and equal reaction!’

With this in mind, it is reasonable to hope for a positive outcome from the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP) standard procedure for track closure and rehabilitation. It is also reasonable to consider that this action could be a catalyst for recognising and promoting the ecotourism potential of Rushworth’s natural environment.

The unprecedented public response to the track closure attracted the attention of a number of key interest groups with a shared objective of preserving and enhancing existing bush tracks within the box-ironbark forest; encouraging their responsible use for locals and visitors alike.

Representatives from the Shire of Campaspe, Goulburn Broken Catchment Management Authority (GBCMA), Parks Victoria, Rushworth Offroad Cycling Association (RORCA) and Rushworth Action Group for the Environment (RAGE) met in Rushworth last week to discuss a vision for the creation of a formal rail-trail ‘artery’ running from Rushworth to Heathcote and beyond.

Readers may be aware of the Murchison Rail-trail that comes to an abrupt halt, halfway to Rushworth. The group learned that the proposal to continue the trail is well under way, with the Shire of Campaspe currently in negotiations with DELWP and Regional Development Victoria to complete the trail to Rushworth and extend it through the forest. This would give rail-trail enthusiasts (and there are plenty) the ability to travel by train from Melbourne to Murchison and cycle the central Victorian gold elds, spending time and tourist dollars in small towns like Rushworth.

The development of additional forest loop tracks and track access to Graytown and Mount Black within Heathcote-Graytown National Park was discussed as a draw-card for cyclists and walkers wanting to explore the environment more intimately away from main roads. Many opportunities were highlighted within the culturally and naturally diverse landscape to enhance existing tracks with up- to-date signage and locally accessible maps. There is also potential to complement tours of the forest with the latest technological applications for the more cyber-savvy users who want an informative exploration of Rushworth’s local forest without carrying a paper map!

Momentum is growing for the development of partnerships, with the aim of creating an integrated, cross-shire border, local nature experience that bush tracks provide, and the conversation will soon include the Shire of Strathbogie.

The irony of the situation is not lost, as the closure of this track may lead to the opening of an entire track system that promotes public appreciation for the bush, public health and a genuine opportunity for the economic growth of small regional towns like Rushworth.

twenty-years-gone-by.title: Waranga Hostel - Twenty years gone by
pars: On a warm and sunny Sunday (19 February 2017),  locals and visitors gathered in the gardens of the Waranga Hostel in Rushworth to help celebrate the hostel’s 20th birthday.
The garden and the setting had been manicured and planned in fine detail to make everyone feel welcome and to put them in a party mood.

Dignitaries were present to give the occasion some gravitas as Clem Furphy guided the occasion through its formalities. About 170 guests - including Steph Ryan Member for Euroa), Sharman Stone (who officially opened the hostel in 1997) and Doug Crow (at that time, the Chief Commissioner of the newly-formed Shire of Campaspe) who turned the first sod. Clem added to the historical touch of the day by bringing along the actual shovel used, but suitably rejuvenated for the occasion with a touch of gold paint!

Also present were Campaspe Mayor, Adrian Weston, Noel Maughan (former Member for Rodney), John and Mark O’Mahoney (the builders), Trevor Saunders (CEO of GV Health) and Jane French (Manager/Director of Nursing of GV Health, Waranga Campus).
A community celebration

But the day belonged to the Hostel and its staff and residents - and the work and coordination of the Friends of the Hostel who had put so much time and effort into making the celebration the great success it was.
Many thanks to all these people (including staff who volunteered their time on the day) who made the Garden Party such a successful community event.
Hostel residents and their families, staff and local guests were treated to a plentiful afternoon tea,   followed by a barbecue later in the day - for anyone who could manage to eat anything more!

Students of Rushworth P-12 College were the very capable and friendly waiting staff serving the tables and the Lions Club manned the sausage sizzle, the Rushworth Concert Band entertained the guests and Murray Ross sketched away in the background.

It was good to acknowledge all those who had been part of the original idea, planning and fund-raising that made the Hostel a reality - and what a boost it’s been for our local area. It has enabled locals in need of care to stay local and to remain part of the community. Its location, right in the centre of Rushworth, means that residents are not cut-off from the town facilities and can always get a yarn if they are up to a walk down the street.
The hostel has also been a boost for training and employment opportunities. Congratulations to all concerned who have all contributed to this great asset for the local community.

farewell-doris.title: Farewell to Doris from the Waranga News
pars: The Waranga News team was saddened to hear of the passing of their long-term valued volunteer, Doris Barlow, last Saturday.

Until 2014 Doris had been one of our longest serving team members, having commenced with the paper in the early 1980’s and serving in a number of roles, including reception, proof-reading and reporting for clubs such as the Senior Citizens. She was also a Waranga News Board member and most recently served as Vice-President for a number of years.

Doris was enthusiastic and committed to the community newspaper cause and regularly attended the annual conferences of the Community Newspapers of Victoria (CNAV) at various venues around the state. She was well-loved in CNAV circles and known for her proud claim to be the oldest attendee there. Although it was past the time she was able to attend conferences, she was still featured on the cover of the Association’s 10th anniversary program!
Farewell Doris from your Waranga News friends, past and present - you are sadly missed.

calling-all-animal-lovers.title: Calling all animal lovers - new volunteer roles available
pars: The Campaspe Animal Shelter is on the lookout for animal lovers with an interest in becoming part of the shelter’s newly-launched Volunteer Program.

Campaspe Mayor, Cr Adrian Weston, said the volunteering opportunities on offer included a broad range of hands-on roles at the shelter as well as foster carers to look after the animals for short periods of time in their own home.

“The Campaspe Animal Shelter provides a safe, temporary place for lost, stray or unwanted dogs and cats until a permanent home can be found, so we are looking for volunteers passionate about providing the highest quality of care for these animals during their stay at the facility,” Cr Weston said.
“This is a wonderful opportunity for the animal lovers in our community to make a positive and valuable contribution to the ongoing physical and psychological wellbeing of these animals.
“All animals at the shelter are tested for temperament and health, so volunteers and foster carers would only care for those that have passed all the tests and have been deemed suitable for adoption.

“As the focus of this council service is to re-home the animals, the quality of care provided by volunteers is vitally important in ensuring each animal has the best possible chance of  nding its forever home.”

To ensure the suitability of volunteers for particular roles, council has a comprehensive volunteer recruitment program in place that includes an expression of interest process, then upon acceptance, formal induction, training and on-site health and safety education.

“This system not only assists us to match volunteers with jobs aligned with their knowledge, skills and experience, it enables prospective volunteers to fully understand what’s involved in becoming a volunteer,” Cr Weston said.

Positions on offer for the current intake of volunteers include general assistants to help with play, exercise and grooming with the Campaspe Animal Shelter. Foster carers are also needed to provide short-term respite within their own home for animals who may have been at the facility for extended periods of time.

Council is holding a public information session on Thursday, 9 March from 6-7pm at the Echuca Civic Centre Function Room for interested members of the public to nd out more about these volunteering opportunities. Further information, including application forms, is also available on Council’s website www.campaspe.vic.gov.au.
Expressions of interest must be received by Council by Monday, 20 March. These can be emailed to shire@campaspe.vic.gov.au or sent to Campaspe Shire Council, PO Box 35, Echuca VIC 3564.
To coordinate an interview or seek further information contact, Communications Unit, 5481 2203, Email: s.ennis@campaspe.vic.gov.au

colbo-primary-celebrates.title: Colbinabbin Primary celebrates 100 years of quality education
pars: Around fifty community members gathered on the lawns of Colbinabbin Primary School recently to launch a year of centenary celebrations for the school. The school children were all dressed in period costume, appropriately setting the scene for celebrating 100 years of education in Colbinabbin.

School leader, Jack McArdle, welcomed all the guests and then added a special welcome to Department of Education colleagues, past principals, past and present school council presidents and councillors, past and present Parent and Friend members, past and present staff members and pupils.

Barrie Winzar, Principal from 1965-1967, addressed the crowd gathered and reminisced fondly about his time at Colbinabbin, with some funny anecdotes, and noted how the physical buildings had changed so much. However he believed that the crowd present was indicative of the fact that the Colbinabbin community spirit had not changed and that this community was indeed still the special place he remembered.
Following this, House Leader, Ned Morgan, and Prep student, Herb Ireland unveiled the centenary plaque.

The next stage of the proceedings saw the burying of a time capsule that had been made by the children. House Leader, Kiara Kaiser, read out a list of all the items that had been placed in the time capsule. Josh Simeon, Green Team Leader, then placed the capsule in the ground and read the plaque to the audience gathered. The ceremony concluded with the children singing a rendition of Waltzing Matilda.

Principal, Robyn MacLean, thanked all those who had worked to prepare the school for the special celebrations. Wendy Morgan, who has taught at the school for many years, then cut the cake depicting a ‘100’ as the crowd gave three cheers for the future of the Colbinabbin Primary School. Those gathered then enjoyed a delicious morning tea prepared by the Colbinabbin parents and coordinated by Centenary Celebrations working group member, Robyn Ryan.
- Robyn MacLean, Colbinabbin Primary School

rushworth-bush-tracks-debate.title: Rushworth’s bush tracks in parliamentary debate
pars: A recent public outcry about the state government’s track-blocking policy has urged a number of state MP’s and local government representatives, to visit the now famous ‘Telstra Trail’.

Social media attention for the ‘Telstra Track’ near Rushworth has brought the standard practice of track- blocking into scrutiny as thousands of comments are recorded from across the nation complaining that public land is becoming increasingly inaccessible.

Last week staff from the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, admitted they were responsible for the widely condemned action of felling track-adjacent trees along seven kilometres of the popular ‘Telstra Trail’ in the Redcastle-Graytown State Forest, near Rushworth. They say this was done to deter trail- bike access and allow the track to regenerate after increased off-road use. Spokesperson, Paul Bates, is quoted saying around one hundred trees were felled across the track; however, a survey conducted by a local resident has recorded one hundred and ninety-three live trees have been destroyed. Over one hundred dead trees and branches have also been dragged across the forest  oor to create obstacles. It was noted that a large machine was used to move and push many of the trees over and that this machinery caused signi cant and widespread damage to countless native understory  ora species.

The vox pop on social media shows that the community is unhappy not only about the environmental damage and access restriction, but also because there was no public consultation. Residents claim that prior to the Department’s actions the track was in good condition with minimal damage. It is described as a good, all-purpose track for walking and cycling on. The department spokesperson stated that walkers and cyclists may continue to use the track but it is evident that the new obstructions present great dif culty and danger to current legal users and that trail-bike riders will now just ride around the felled trees and cause further damage to the environment. A trail-bike rider on social media claimed that the obstacles will just make the track more of a challenge. It is interesting to note that not until after the works were complete, were signs erected advising users of restricted access. The attempt to prevent illegal use of the area has also encouraged the illegal collection of  rewood, with people already removing the fallen trees.

The clear message that has been voiced to the environment minister by a number of state MPs in parliament is that forests should be able to be appropriately used by the public, but environmental concerns, including forest conservation and protection of ecosystems, must also be addressed.

The department has acknowledged that in hindsight it should have done things differently, but unfortunately there is no way to turn back time. Instead the minister must look into the situation and create safeguards to protect the environment from future similar actions as well as to allow the public fair access and ongoing use.

welcome-preps-2017.title: Welcome to Prep/Foundation students for 2017
pars: The start of the 2017 year brought with it a name change for some prep students. Foundation students is the new term used to describe preps, this was introduced to give a national uniform approach.

heart-breaking-end.title: Heart breaking end to search
pars: We are saddened by the news, the police have confirmed after a three day search, divers have recovered the body of the missing 21 year old Rushworth man, feared drowned. The man went missing last Saturday afternoon, after entering the channel and not resurfacing. The incident occurred on Channel Inlet road, a channel that leads into the Waranga Basin. Our hearts go out to the family and friends.

residents-have-a-say.title: Residents still able to have a say
pars: More than 330 residents took the time on Saturday (4 February) to join in the Campaspe Conversation event, chatting to councillors and staff.
Mayor, Cr Adrian Weston, said the event, held for the fifth year, was a success and councillors enjoyed meeting many residents across the region.
“I thank community members who took the time to meet with us on Saturday, it was great to hear first-hand your views and comments.”

“Echuca was much busier this year, with Kyabram, Rushworth and Rochester similar in numbers. This year we also added Gunbower in the Western Ward, and although quiet, provided an opportunity for residents to participate.”
“The conversation was quite varied, from current shire-wide issues, to a general chat and catch-up, to lodging a service request.”
“To date we have received 155 responses through our survey, but will leave the survey open through to 17 February to give residents time to participate,” Cr Weston said.

“A quick review of the responses to date shows that 80% did not participate in last year’s event, similar to last year at 83% - which is good news that we have connected with even more people from across our shire.”
Staff had access to the IT system to assist in the lodgement or follow-up of service requests as well as the use of iPads for survey responses.
“I wish to thank our staff who gave up their Saturday morning to assist councillors with this event.”
A full review of the survey information will be undertaken once the survey is closed and will be reported back to the community in the March community newsletter.
The survey can be accessed via council’s website, or directly at link https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/convoday

bridge-construction-imminent.title: Start Of Works On Echuca Moama Second Bridge Imminent
pars: Start of construction of the Echuca Moama second bridge is imminent with all formal approvals now in place.

“With ministerial approval of the planning scheme amendment needed to lock in the land, and public gazetting of the project on 1 December 2016, we are thrilled that all check boxes have now been ticked, giving the green light for works to begin on the Echuca Moama second bridge crossing,” Campaspe Mayor, Cr Adrian Weston, said.
“Bringing this project to fruition has been a high priority and ongoing advocacy issue of council and the community for many years, so this is fantastic news for our entire shire.”

Formal approval of Amendment C103 to Campaspe’s Planning Scheme reserves the land required for the project, and sets out planning controls to ensure that any impact on the environment and community are managed. This, together with the land identifi ed for the new crossing in Moama that was previously approved in the Review of Environmental Factors in NSW, formalises the project to be built along the Mid West Option.
“Benefits of the new bridge will be signifi cant and wide-ranging,” Cr Weston said.

“In addition to the regional economic and social advantages, the communities of Echuca and Moama, which rely heavily on the crossing for employment, tourism and emergency services, will benefi t greatly on a daily basis and in a very tangible way.
“We now look forward to the opening of the VicRoads project office on site later this month, signalling to residents that project implementation is finally underway.”

carnage-in-state-forest.title: Carnage in Rushworth State Forest
pars: Hundreds of trees have been destroyed in Rushworth State Forest, south of Whroo, in what appears to be an attempt to discourage dirt-bike use in the area.

The felled Box and Ironbark trees have been deliberately pushed down over an extended stretch of one of the key trails in the area, rendering it unusable to cyclists and an inconvenience and danger to walkers and other legal trail users.
The affected trail – affectionately known to local walkers and mountain-bikers as the ‘Telecom Line’ or ‘Telecom Trail’ – runs deep into the forest from Rushworth.

The carnage starts south of Whroo where the trail crosses over Rushworth-Graytown Road and continues for approximately 7km. The felled trees cover the track at regular intervals and show scrape marks and other obvious signs of being pushed over by heavy equipment.

Visiting mountain-bikers, a small but growing group of recreational users who enjoy the beauty of the Rushworth State Forest, have been reporting the discovery to a local mountain-biking association this week. There are no signs or any other information warning trail users of the changed conditions in the area.

The destruction is said to be deliberate to discourage dirt-bikers from using the trails. The environmental damage and destruction of one of the area’s most popular trails has drawn the ire of locals and the online community.
A Facebook video documenting the destruction had been viewed more than 12,500 times in less than 24 hours and attracted the interest of State MP’s as this article was written.

herb-is-the-one.title: Herb is the One!
pars: This year Colbinabbin Primary welcomed just one prep child to the school. Herb Ireland will join big brother, Lenny at school - and he is sure to receive plenty of attention! Although the sole preppie, there are no worries about Herb settling confidently into school life after participating in the school’s term four Pre-Prep Program last year.

australia-day-celebrated.title: Australia Day celebrated
pars: Australia Day was marked across the region with community celebrations and citizens being recognised for outstanding contribution to their local communities.
In Rushworth about 150 people attended in the cool comfort of the Shire Hall, with its comfortable seats and notable absence of biting insects.

Activities kicked off with the traditional barbeque hosted by the Rushworth & District Lions Club and drinks provided by the members of the local SES Unit. Our much admired band played during the BBQ, and also performed the National Anthem and a concert piece when the official entertainment started at 6 pm.
A number of local entertainers performed before Mayor Adrian Weston addressed the audience with some personal thoughts about Australia Day.

More entertainment followed and guest speaker Bob Holschier delivered a fascinating discourse on some little-known historic events in Rushworth and Whroo, explaining many of the unusual things that we all take for granted.
The evening climaxed with the presentation of awards by Mayor Adrian Weston and Bob, after which the evening closed with a somewhat shortened version of “I Still Call Australia Home”.
Waranga Ward winners
Citizen of the Year - Doug Gray
Young Citizen of the Year - Not awarded
Sportsperson of the Year - Alexandrea Bethell
Junior Sportsperson of the Year - Not Awarded
Community Group of the Year - Stanhope & District Men’s Shed
Arts Person of the Year - Tony (Anthony) Crosbie
* Doug Gray was also selected as the Shire of Campaspe’s Citizen of the Year. (See page 6)
Rushworth township awards
This year two local Rushworth awards were presented.
Citizen of the Year went to Ray Barber, in recognition of his many years of service to Rushworth Easter Festival and Rushworth SES Unit.
A Special Commendation was also awarded to Lorraine Lloyd for dedicated service as School Crossing Lollipop Lady for many years.

a-fresh-approach.title: A fresh approach
pars: Rushworth Garden Festival, spread over two weekends this year, was once again a great success. The Garden Expo on the second weekend was a vibrant collection of plant stalls, handmade craft, garden produce, live music and guest speakers. The community joyfully embraced the new concept and an atmosphere of sharing and promise for the future resonated throughout the village green. Organisers are to be applauded for their initiative and the above image of the P-12 kitchen garden produce emulates this fresh approach.

council-elections-see-some-new-faces.title: Council elections see some new faces
pars: Council election results have been declared in much of the State, with Campaspe Shire Council results officially announced on Monday morning (31 October). Four new councillors have been elected, three in the Echuca Ward and one in Kyabram.
The nine successful candidates representing the five wards for the Campaspe Shire Council are:
Echuca Ward: Annie Vickers, Daniel Mackrell, Kristen Munro
Kyabram Deakin Ward: Neil Pankhurst, Vicki Neele, John Zobec
Rochester Ward: Leigh Wilson
Western Ward: Leanne Pentreath
Waranga Ward: Adrian Weston
Chief Executive Officer, Jason Russell, congratulated the successful candidates and thanked retiring and outgoing councillors for their service.
“We have a new council with a good blend of experienced and new councillors and with four female councillors, the highest representation of females we have had on council to date.”
Waranga Ward Councillor Adrian Weston also noted the improved gender balance which was reflected across the State.

“It’s good to see four women elected to Council and four new councillors. I’m looking forward to some new and fresh thinking and am feeling positive about the potential for this new group of councillors to achieve some good community outcomes during the next four years,” he said.
The statutory meeting, where councillors will take the Oath of Office, sign the Code of Conduct and officially elect the Mayor, will be held on Tuesday, 8 November at 5pm.

huge-stanhope-weekend.title: Huge Stanhope weekend
pars: Hundreds turn out to celebrate Stanhope School’s 100 years.
Hundreds of visitors, many former residents of Stanhope, came back to town last weekend to celebrate the centenary of their old school.
The celebrations commenced on Friday with the local school children, their parents and friends, launching one hundred balloons to celebrate the one hundred years life of the school (pictured above).
Many visiting former students and staff inspected the school during the afternoon, along with all its modern facilities.

Saturday was the main day of celebrations, with more than 300 people attending the school to inspect the facilities, together with a photo display of students from years gone by, but most importantly, to catch up with former friends and mates from their school days, some more recent, but most from many years ago. There were many memories revived and stories told of years gone by (mostly true, but some perhaps a little exaggerated).
The afternoon concluded with photos being taken of groups of former students, representing the ten decades of the school.

Following such a successful day, the dinner in the Stanhope Community Hall was just as successful, with more than one hundred attending. Once again stories from the past were related by some of the very senior students, including Mr David Bell, the oldest living former student, now in his mid nineties. The members of the organising committee were rightly ecstatic with the highly successful weekend.

mini-market-another-great-success.title: P12 Mini Market another great success… YEP it was!
pars: What a great community we live in!
Staff and students were thrilled with the recent support from the community regarding their Mini Market on Wednesday 7 September.
The Year 4/5/6 students and Year 9/10 YEP students had worked tirelessly since the last market to bring their customers some new, improved experiences.

The barista’s were busy honing their skills, the pizza boys did a mammoth job not only cooking pizza’s for those who attended the Market, but for the majority of students who had ordered one or more for lunch that day! The ‘craft’ teams had been busy making ‘things’. Who would have guessed those ‘cookies in a jar’ would be such a HOT item?
This group of willing workers raised over $700, the best one ever!
They say there is no rest for the wicked and these groups of students (who are a long way from wicked), have already begun planning for the two final events of 2016.

The students are excited to be joining in the festivities of the Rushworth Spring Garden Festival Fair on Saturday 29 October - 10am until 2pm. They will have a stall promoting the Stephanie Alexander Kitchen Garden as well as a range of ‘garden inspired’ goods for sale!
They will also hold another Mini Market at the College in November, with a Christmas theme, the date of which will be established early next term.
Thank you again to everyone who supported this event. The students hope to see you all again at their next two events.

fire-destroys-homestead.title: Fire destroys Rushworth homestead
pars: When firefighters from Rushworth and Stanhope Brigades were paged out to a structure fire in Parramatta Gully Road early on Saturday morning, first responders were stunned to find the house already “fully involved”, even though the fire had been reported promptly and fire appliances arrived within minutes of the call.
Fortunately, the occupants of the house escaped the blaze, but decades of priceless memorabilia relating to the eucalyptus factory and its succession of owners was destroyed.
The fire is likely to have been caused by a combustion heater, which can be seen in the above photo with a damaged front glass.

wildflower-hunt.title: Wildflower hunt this weekend
pars: The sun is starting to shine again and it’s time to welcome in the new season by unlocking Rushworth’s hidden treasures at the second annual Wildflower Hunt.
Explore the vast array of native wildflowers in the Rushworth Ironbark Forest on Sunday 28 August at 10am meeting at the Rushworth Cemetery.

Participants can explore the forest following a set 6km route with some side routes for the more adventurous. An array of wildflowers will be in bloom, such as downy grevillea, flax lilies, autumn greenhoods, correas, grey everlastings, brachyscome and much more. In addition to wildflowers there will be birds and other wildlife to see as well as historic sites and relics from the gold mining days.

Included in this year’s Wildflower Hunt is the option of taking a guided botanical walk or a guided bird walk along the route given by local experts in the Rushworth Ironbark Forest. Also offered will be a self guided tour of the Rushworth cemetery which is the start and end point of the walk, showcasing some of the stories behind the people buried there.

new-easter-festival-committee.title: New Committee steps up for Easter Festival
pars: Rushworth’s popular Easter Festival is set to go ahead for 2017 with the election of a new Festival Committee and Parade Coordinator.

Following the Rushworth Easter Festival Inc AGM in July which failed to elect a new committee, a public meeting was held on Monday evening, with a view to either electing a new committee or winding up the incorprated body.
The full house (about forty people) indicated there was plenty of interest in keeping the festival alive and, after an intially slow start, a new committee came forward to takeover the reigns.
The meeting was unanimous in expressing congratulations and gratitude to the previous committee members, many of whom had been the driving force behind the Easter Festival since its beginning.

state-of-the-forest.title: State of the forest raises concern
pars: A very disappointing discovery in the State forest near Whroo of some of the area’s iconic Grass Trees which have been destroyed through an act of environmental vandalism. The species is known for its slow growth rate and stunning form as it inhabits the forest floor in clusters and provides habitat for grounddwelling species such as the wallaby. Neil Laurie was recently embarrassed by the state of the forest when showing visitors around.

chief-celebrates.title: Chief celebrates 90 years
pars: Ninety years, twenty grandchildren and twenty five great-grandchildren can only be classed as a great achievement. On Sunday 12 June, Chief (Jeff) Perry celebrated his 90th birthday with over a hundred family and friends at the Rushworth Football and Netball Clubrooms.
While the formal event was held on the Sunday afternoon, the celebration was enjoyed over several days.

Chief likes nothing better than to have family around him and in particular he loves his grandchildren visiting. During the long weekend Chief’s home was filled with family and he thoroughly enjoyed sitting round the camp fire and joining in the singing and sharing of yarns.

Chief particularly enjoyed spending time with family members who travelled from afar for the celebrations and their efforts to travel were greatly appreciated. Chief was also surprised by the Rushworth Brass Band which attended the Sunday venue and played Happy Birthday, as well as a number of other pieces. Chief has been associated with the Band for many years and their attendance brought him much pleasure.

editor-awarded-order-of-australia-medal.title: Waranga News Editor awarded Order of Australia Medal
pars: Our own Dr Mary Jo Fortuna of Rushworth has been awarded an Order of Australia Medal in the latest Queen’s Birthday honours list.

The closely guarded news was kept amazingly ‘secret’ and embargoed, but with the publishing of the honours list last Monday, the news spread like wildfire, with the Waranga News Editor beseiged by phone calls at the News office and filming interviews for WIN news television screening.

Anyone who’s known Mary Jo will appreciate the service she has given the various local and university campuses over the years. But few would know her full involvement until the reading of the citation was published, and there are probably many other services that have not made it to the list!
Need we note that Mary Jo, herself, was quite overwhelmed by the attention and commented that she had nearly forgotten some of her various involvements.
Retirement ~ not exactly!

Although Mary Jo retired from lecturing and co-ordinating the Social Science faculty at the Shepparton Campus of La Trobe University in 2014, her days of pottering in the garden (as she had envisaged) have not exactly come to fruition. She was head-hunted to work with the St Vincent de Paul Society as Social Justice coordinator for the NorthEast Central region which often takes her off to Shepparton or Melbourne for meetings (just when we need her here), and her work in St Mary’s Parish includes playing music and being a member of the Parish Pastoral Council.

As well as all this, involvement in her large family’s events and celebrations make many calls on her - well, with her seven children now married and twelve grandchildren, there are always reasons to gather!

waranga-trail-progress.title: Waranga Trail - a small step closer
pars: Rushworth residents with long memories will know it’s been a long time coming, but construction of the local rail trail appears to be one step closer to becoming a reality. Now known as the Waranga Trail, the signing of land management agreements has been endorsed by Campaspe Shire Council so that external funding negotiations can go ahead.

Campaspe Mayor, Cr Leigh Wilson, said Council’s endorsement of the project would facilitate negotiations with grant bodies and partner organisations to secure funding to deliver the project some time in the future.
“The Waranga Trail has been a subject of consideration by the local community and Council for over ten years,” Cr Wilson said.

Over the past six months, Council has undertaken feasibility studies and cost/benefit analyses to assess the viability of the trail project. This information can now form the basis of a business case which will position the project as an attractive funding proposition.

The proposed Waranga Trail includes the rail trail from Murchison to Rushworth and a connecting trail through to Heathcote. Scoping and estimates for the section of the trail, from Rushworth eastwards to the shire boundary towards Murchison and the section from Heathcote to Rushworth, have now been completed.

Discussions and negotiations have been held with VicTrack, Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, Goulburn Murray Water, Parks Victoria, City of Greater Bendigo and private land holders. Consultation has also included Regional Development Victoria to affirm the potential viability of securing funding support.
“Based on these consultations, we have concluded that construction of both reaches of the trail is feasible and will generate a positive return on investment,” the Mayor said.
An interim costing predicts the Rushworth to Murchison link will cost approximately $1.2 million and the Heathcote to Rushworth link will cost approximately $1.1 million.

The Waranga Trail is identified as a key Shire of Campaspe project in the Regional Development Australia prospectus. Council officers have undertaken more detailed work seeking to secure access rights to the trail route to eliminate risks and issues should the project be funded.

“Council’s endorsement of the project and signing of agreements with VicTrack and Goulburn Murray Water to secure tenure of land will demonstrate our full commitment to potential external funding bodies,” Cr Wilson said.

However it’s not all in the bag yet. External grant opportunities are likely to require Council to match any funding contribution dollar for dollar. Council says it is committed to negotiating with stakeholders and partners to a point where the project is ready to go should the funding become available.

While the project does not extend to a trail linking Girgarre to Rushworth at present, Council acknowledges this would have the capacity to generate positive health and wellbeing outcomes for local residents.

Council officers will continue to facilitate negotiations to allow the Girgarre Development Committee to assume management of DELWP land between Girgarre and Stanhope to extend the existing small community-owned trail.

mavis-celebrating-102.title: Mavis celebrating 102 years
pars: Mavis Hunt celebrated her 102nd birthday with family & friends at Moyola Lodge, Tatura, on 24 May. An avid reader, Mavis always enjoys getting her Waranga News to catch up with the local events. She asked her daughter, Maggie Johnston, to say ‘thank you’ on her behalf for the beautiful cards, flowers and good wishes she received for her birthday.

freak-storm-strikes.title: Freak storm strikes Rushworth area
pars: When ferocious winds and torrential rain impacted parts of Rushworth last week, it left some areas of the district looking like a war zone. Trees were up-rooted or had large parts of their canopies snapped off, and intense downpours occurred over some areas while others escaped virtually unscathed. These photos by Cass Alexander show the storm in action and some of its aftermath.
Rushworth Observatory recorded 30mm of rain in a five minute deluge that quickly left the domed telescope housing surrounded by water. Huge rain drops pelted down, as seen in the photo at right.

Trees toppled near Murchison, and the RushworthTatura Road was blocked by foliage dislodged from roadside trees (above). One tree on Chief Perry’s property was uprooted completely by the fierce winds (below).

Members of Rushworth Fire Brigade quickly initiated a cleanup operation, and were soon assisted by a front-end loader and driver from a nearby construction crew, and a local motorist who arrived with a chainsaw (lower right).

A VicRoads crew also arrived on scene, and the cleared road was finally given a final wash-down by the tanker’s powerful front monitor. The highway was reopened within a half hour, and traffic was soon moving once again
It was a great team effort by all of those involved.

save-local-pools.title: Move to save local pools
pars: Small town communities in the Shire of Campaspe have come out in force to save their much-loved community facility, their local swimming pool, from being decomissioned.

While Council claims the proposed changes are necessary cost-cutting measures, and that limited resources must be used to provide services to the greatest number of people, small town residents feel their own community needs are as important as the bigger centres and are at present being overlooked.

trees-last-stand.title: Trees last stand
pars: Despite the best efforts of the Rushworth Action Group for the Environment (RAGE) and its many supporters, roadworks have commenced this week that will see 91 trees removed from the RushworthTatura Road entrance to town.
However, all was not lost in the the RAGE campaign to protect Rushworth’s old-growth roadside trees, with 65 of those originally slated for removal now being retained.

Other compromises reached in negotiations with VicRoads include reduction in the speed limit from 100kph to 80kph for an extended distance along the winding road and reduction in the extent of the use of wire rope and steel guard railing.
In addition, all of the timber from the felled trees will be retained in the town for the use of the community.

a-legendairy-winner.title: A Legendairy Australia Day winner
pars: Members of the Stanhope & District Development Committee (S&DDC) were delighted to learn their nomination, Andrew Hipwell, was declared Citizen of the Year in the Rushworth District and also Citizen of the Year across the Shire of Campaspe.
The S&DDC considered Andrew to be a very worthy recipient of the awards, following his efforts of the past few years, in bringing a great deal of awareness of Stanhope across Victoria and Australia.
His work with the young people of the Stanhope District, through his and their involvement and participation with Auskick, has been greatly appreciated by many parents.

However, his involvement with all the Stanhope community in playing a major role, together with others, by successfully nominating Stanhope for recognition as “The Legendairy Capital of Australia “ has been outstanding and strengthened the resolve of the S&DDC in nominating Andrew for the award.

Secretary of the S&DDC, Bob Holschier, said members were absolutely delighted to see that Andrew has been fittingly recognised for his tremendous work during the past few years. Mr Holschier stated, “We were very encouraged with putting forward Andrew’s nomination, when we received so many supporting letters from the various organisations Andrew was involved with, that brought so much recognition Australia - wide to Stanhope”. These supporting letters came from Dairy Australia, Fonterra, AFL, Murray Goulburn region, the Stanhope Primary School and parents of children involved with Auskick.

save-the-trees.title: Community rallies to save trees
pars: Rushworth residents have come out in force to express their alarm at VicRoads plans to remove more than 120 mature indigenous trees along the Tatura-Rushworth Road leading into the town.
As contractors arrived to commence work, word quickly spread and at the eleventh hour a group of local residents gathered and succeeded in temporarily halting the scheduled road works.

On extremely short notice, the group, instigated by Louise Costa, Les Pelle and Sharon Carey, rallied other concerned locals to the site at the truck parking bay on the Tatura- Rushworth Road two kilometres out of Rushworth.
The group was able to convince VicRoads project managers to postpone the extensive roadside ‘remodelling’ which would see 123 indigenous trees removed from the landscape.
Need to consult
Local outrage focussed on the loss of such a large number of trees without community consultation.
While contractors waited in the background it was pointed out to managers that VicRoads plans to undertake such a project without informing or consulting the local community was not on.

Eventually it was agreed that the project should be postponed and the community issues resolved before continuing work. It was admitted there had been no intention to inform local residents and conceded that it was appropriate to do so.
The contractors were sent home and VicRoads has agreed to hold a public meeting to explain the extent of the project and answer questions.
Scheduled to start as soon as possible, the project would see roadworks continue for two months. It also includes widening the road and constructing four kilometres of wire guard rails.
VicRoads has suggested that the reason for the road change is traffic safety based on recent accident reports for the road, however there is no intention to reduce the speed limit.

centenary-anzac-day.title: Record crowds mark Centenary ANZAC Day
pars: ANZAC Day was observed around the district with particular fervour and record attendances in this year commemorating the landing at Gallipoli 100 years ago. Included in the day were special ceremonies - the opening of a War Memorial in Corop and the unveiling of a plaque to honour Vietnam Veterans in Rushworth.

Poppies marked each of the names on the old Shire of Waranga Honour Roll boards at the Memorial, a labour of love by Mary Beck and Mavis Raglus. More  oral tributes were added throughout the day, as a succession of wreaths were laid by people representing many generations of our community.

Rushworth’s 2015 Anzac Day Dawn Service began with powerful words from local RSL President, Bill Barlow. “Welcome to you all on this most signi cant occasion, arguably the most important anniversary and the most important centenary in our nation’s history.

“(Anzac Day) is our day when we as a nation remember all those who have fought and died for their country in time of con ict, but especially this morning. “We remember and honour not only those original Anzacs who landed at Gallipoli 100 years ago today, but all Australians and our brother New Zealanders who fought and died for the cause of freedom in that most horrendous and tragic period in our nation’s history”.
As more than three hundred people gathered around Rushworth’s High Street War Memorial, the ritual was played out with great solemnity and respect.

Those assembled heard the poignant words of a letter written to local loved ones on 24 April by Charlie Bale, a man who was to die the very next day. The Ode about not growing old was followed by the Last Post, a minute’s silence and the Reveille, the familiar sequence that is at once haunting and uplifting.

community-life.title: Community - life is all about that!
pars: You meet the nicest people in Rushworth’s Community Garden - that’s where Chief Perry and Marcie Martin caught up recently over pizza. Pizza Days in the Garden regularly attract a wide variety of people getting together for great food and first class companionship.
